Title: The Blood of the Sages
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
The room is dimly lighted, with tall shelves stacked with books, old maps, and globes. A dark red table is in the middle of the room and on it sits a quill with a bottle of ink. A man is hunched over a parchment, writing with a quill.
INT. STUDY - MOMENTS LATER
The man is looking apprehensive, and he takes a small knife he uses for opening his letters. He runs the tip of the blade through the candle flame, then makes a small cut and a few blood drops fall on the table. He dips the quill in the blood and as he gets prepared to sign his name at the bottom of the page, black letters spontaneously appear on his arm.
MR. ALEXANDER
(looking at his arm with wonder)
How did they get there?
He rolls up his sleeve to get a better look and the letters on his arm blur and fade away. He looks back at the paper in front of him, and begins to write.
MR. ALEXANDER (CONT'D)
(writing)
And so, the line is drawn...
He looks at the ink on the quill and suddenly a thought occurs to him. He moves his quill and starts to write the letters from his arm onto the paper.
MR. ALEXANDER (CONT'D)
(writing)
Blood is the mark of death.
He puts the quill down, but then picks it up again and starts to write again.
MR. ALEXANDER (CONT'D)
(writing)
And life.
He looks back at his arm and the letters are still there. He begins to write more.
MR. ALEXANDER (CONT'D)
(writing)
The blood of the sages.
He picks up the knife again and cuts his arm. He lets it bleed into a small bowl. He takes the bowl and dips the quill into it.
MR. ALEXANDER (CONT'D)
(writing)
The blood of the sages.
The letters on his arm start to fade away and he looks at the paper. It is now filled with black letters. He reads what he has written and a smile creeps across his face.
MR. ALEXANDER (CONT'D)
(writing)
I have done it.
He puts his quill down and walks to the shelves. He picks up a book and starts to read.
MR. ALEXANDER (CONT'D)
(reading)
"The blood of the sages is the key to the eternal."
His face lights up and he starts to laugh.
MR. ALEXANDER (CONT'D)
This was all I needed.
He closes the book and puts it back on the shelf. He walks to the door and unlocks it. He walks out of the room and down the stairs.
EXT. HOUSE - MOMENTS LATER
He walks out the front door and walks down the street. He passes a car and gets into it. He puts the key in the ignition and turns it on. He pulls out onto the street.
EXT. CITY - A FEW MOMENTS LATER

Can I get a full tank of gas, please?

MR. ALEXANDER

Can I also get a pack of cigarettes, please?

INT. HOUSE - THE NEXT DAY

(writing)
The blood of the sages is the key to the eternal.
He puts the book down and walks over to the shelf. He picks up a smaller book and starts to read.
MR. ALEXANDER (CONT'D)
(reading)
"The blood of the sages is the key to the eternal."

[Writing Prompt]: A dinner scene. A large dining table, with different kinds of food and expensive cutlery. The guests are well-dressed and well-rehearsed in etiquette. A senior member of the family announces a change in his will. Everybody on the table is horrified.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and long enough.

Title: A Change of Heart
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
A large dining table with expensive cutlery and different kinds of food is set up for a dinner party. All the guests are sitting at the table, well-dressed and well-rehearsed in their etiquette. A SENIOR FAMILY MEMBER stands at the head of the table.
SENIOR FAMILY MEMBER
Dear family, we have a family announcement to make.
Everyone looks at him with a mix of confusion and annoyance.
SENIOR FAMILY MEMBER
I have made a change to my will.
A woman at the table, MRS. RICHARDSON, looks shocked. She puts her fork down.
MRS. RICHARDSON
What?
SENIOR FAMILY MEMBER
I'm afraid this will come as a surprise to some of you.
Someone at the table, MR. RICHARDSON, starts to protest.
MR. RICHARDSON
This is ridiculous!
SENIOR FAMILY MEMBER
It is not ridiculous. I have made this decision after much thought and deliberation. I have decided to leave my fortune to my granddaughter, Sarah.
MR. RICHARDSON
Sarah? But she's not even related to the family!
SENIOR FAMILY MEMBER
That is correct. She is not. But she is special to me and I want to make sure she will have everything she needs.
MRS. RICHARDSON
But what about the rest of us?
SENIOR FAMILY MEMBER
You will all still receive your fair share. I haven't forgotten about you.
MR. RICHARDSON
This is unacceptable!
SARAH, who is sitting at the opposite end of the table, looks uncomfortable. She looks at her grandfather, then looks down at her plate.
SENIOR FAMILY MEMBER
I am sorry if this comes as a shock to you but I have made up my mind.
MR. RICHARDSON
You will be hearing from our lawyer. This is ridiculous, you can't just change your will like this.
Sarah looks up at her grandfather, tears in her eyes.
SARAH
I'm sorry, Grandfather.
Everyone looks at her, then turns their attention back to their grandfather.
SENIOR FAMILY MEMBER
You have nothing to be sorry for, Sarah. I'm doing what I think is best.
MR. RICHARDSON
This is absurd!
MRS. RICHARDSON
I'm surprised at all of you.

You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A married couple is having a fight about the wife's infidelity. Things get heated, and then the husband confesses to having multiple affairs. Suddenly both of them stop talking. There is heavy silence between the two spouses.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and long enough.
response:
Title: The Secret They Kept
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
The camera pans over the dark room, focusing on a bed where a woman, JENNY (30s), lies awake. She hears the sound of her husband, MICHAEL (30s), entering the room. They exchange a brief goodnight kiss before getting into bed.
Jenny
What happened tonight?
Michael
What do you mean?
Jenny
You weren't yourself. You were angry, like you never are. What's going on?
Michael
Jenny, I had a hard day at work. I'm sorry about the way I acted.
Jenny
It's okay. I understand. But I just need to know. You weren't yourself.
Michael
Jenny, everything is fine. I promise.
Jenny
Just tell me.
Michael sighs, then looks at Jenny.
Michael
I cheated on you.
Jenny is shocked, and she looks at Michael in disbelief.
Jenny
What?
Michael
Jenny, I cheated on you. I had an affair.
Jenny
Why?
Jenny is angry now, as Michael looks at the ground.
Jenny
Why? What did I do?
Michael
Jenny, I need you to understand. I didn't do this to hurt you. I did this because I needed something.
Jenny
You needed something? What do you mean?
Michael
I need to be wanted, Jenny. Loved. I didn't realize it before, but I've been feeling this way for a while now.
Jenny
But I love you. I thought you loved me.
Michael
I do love you. But not in the way I need to be loved. Can you understand?
Jenny
I don't know. I don't understand.
Michael
Jenny, I'm sorry. But you have to believe me. I didn't mean to hurt you.
Jenny is silent for a moment, then gets up, walks over to the bedside table, and grabs her phone.
Jenny
You're not leaving this room until I say so. And you're not going anywhere until we talk about this. I need to know what happened.
Michael nods, and Jenny sits back down next to him.
Michael
You want to know everything?
Jenny nods.
Michael
I've been cheating on you for a while now. For a few months, actually.
Jenny
How many times?
Michael
Three times, I think.
Jenny is shocked.
Jenny
Three times?
Michael nods again.
Jenny
Why did you do this?
Michael looks at the ground again.
Michael
I don't know. I just needed something. Feedback, I guess. I didn't know what else to do.
Jenny
Is there anyone else?
Michael
No. I wouldn't do anything like that. I love you, Jenny. I love you more than anything.
Jenny
Then why did you do this?
Michael
I don't know. I guess I just wanted to feel wanted. To feel like someone else cared about me. But I never meant to hurt you. I don't know what to do now.
Jenny
What do you mean, what to do now?
Michael
I don't know what to do. I don't know if we can work through this.
Jenny
I don't know what to do either. I don't know if we can work through this.
Michael
Jenny, I'm sorry. I didn't mean to hurt you.
Jenny
Michael, why didn't you just talk to me about this? Why didn't you just tell me what was going on?
Michael
I didn't know what to say. I didn't know how to say it.
Jenny
Why didn't you just tell me you needed something? Why did you have to cheat on me?
Michael
I don't know.
Jenny
This is all so stupid. I can't believe you would do something like this.
Michael
I know. I'm sorry.
Jenny
You're sorry? That's it? You're sorry? You think being sorry is enough?
Michael
I don't know what to do. I don't know how to fix this.
Jenny
Michael, this is not something we can just fix. I can't believe you would do this to me.
Michael
I know. I'm sorry.
Jenny
I don't know if I can forgive you.
Michael
I don't know if I can forgive myself.
Jenny
Michael, I need some time to think. I need to process all of this.
Michael nods.
Jenny
You have to leave. I need some time to think.
Jenny gets up and walks out of the room, leaving Michael alone in the dark.
Michael
Jenny, wait.
Jenny stops, looking back at Michael.
Jenny
What?
Michael
Please don't leave me.
Jenny
I just need some time to think.
Jenny turns and walks out of the room, leaving Michael alone in the dark.
Michael
Jenny.
Jenny stops, looking back at Michael.
Jenny
What do you want from me?
Michael
I need you to stay.
Jenny
Michael.
Michael
Jenny, please don't leave me.
Jenny
I just need some time.
Michael nods, and Jenny turns and walks out of the room.
Michael
Jenny.

Jenny
What?
Michael
I love you.
Jenny
I love you too. But I don't know if we can work through this.
Michael
Please don't leave me.
Jenny
I need to think.
Michael
Please, Jenny. I don't know how to live without you.
Jenny
I'll be back. I promise.
Jenny turns and walks out of the room, leaving Michael alone in the dark.

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A person packs her belongings into card boxes because she plans to move into a new apartment. She finds a photo of her and her best friend. A moment of happiness on her face is quickly substituted for a sad, nostalgic smile.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and long enough.
response:
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
The sound of footsteps echoes through an empty hallway. A woman, around 30 years old, is carrying a cardboard box. She sets it down, slightly out of breath, and continues on her way.
The woman stops in the middle of the room. Her eyes scan her surroundings. Memories of this place start flooding back. She remembers waking up every morning and having breakfast in the kitchen. She remembers coming home after a long day of work and sinking into the couch to watch a movie. She remembers all the times she hung out with her best friend on the living room floor.
The woman lets out a sigh. She begins to rummage through the boxes scattered around the living room. She pulls out a photo. It's of her and her best friend. A moment of happiness on her face is quickly substituted for a sad, nostalgic smile.
WOMAN (to herself): I can't believe it's been two years already.
Her gaze shifts to the calendar on the wall. She squints her eyes to read the date. Her eyes widen. She can't believe it's been two years.
WOMAN (to herself): I'm leaving.
She puts the photo back in its box. She takes one last look around the room before heading out of the door.
EXT. APARTMENT BUILDING - NIGHT
The woman makes her way to her car. She puts the key in the ignition and turns it on. She takes one last look at her apartment, then puts the car in drive and speeds off.
The woman pulls into a parking lot. She gets out of the car and walks towards the front door. She stops for a moment and takes a deep breath.
She opens the door and walks inside. The walls are painted in shades of green and blue. The furniture is mostly made out of wood. She puts down her boxes and takes off her coat.
She makes her way to the kitchen. She walks up to the fridge and opens it. She stares inside for a moment, then closes it. She goes to the living room. She sits down on the couch and stares at the blank walls.
She pulls out her phone and scrolls through it. Her eyes land on a message from her best friend.
BEST FRIEND: Hey. I was just wondering when you're going to be moving in.
The woman opens her mouth, but then closes it. She doesn't know what to say.
She gets up and walks over to the window. She looks outside. She sees the other apartments in the building. She sees the people coming and going.
She turns around and walks back to the couch. She sits down again and pulls out a notepad. She starts writing.
She writes about her new apartment, about her best friend, about the memories from her old apartment. She writes about everything she's done so far in her life, and everything she wants to do in the future.
She writes for hours, not noticing the time passing. She stops writing when she runs out of paper. She looks at the pages she's written on. She smiles.
She gets up and walks to the kitchen. She makes a pot of coffee. She walks back to the couch and sits down. She takes a sip of the coffee.
She closes her eyes and takes a deep breath. She feels at peace.
She takes another sip of her coffee. She hears a knock on the door. She gets up and walks to the door. She opens it and sees her best friend standing there.
BEST FRIEND: Hey, I was wondering when you're going to be moving in.
The woman smiles and opens the door wider. Her best friend walks inside and closes the door behind her.
BEST FRIEND: Wow, you already moved in?
Woman (smiling): Yup.
Her best friend sees the notepad on the couch. She picks it up and starts reading.
BEST FRIEND: Wow, you've been writing this whole time?
The woman nods.
BEST FRIEND: So, what are you going to do now?
The woman shrugs.
BEST FRIEND: You know, you could try and find a new apartment and start all over again.
The woman looks at her best friend and smiles.
WOMAN: That's a great idea!
The woman gets up and walks to the door. She opens it and looks outside.
WOMAN: You know what? Let's do it!
The woman and her best friend walk out of the apartment and start walking down the hallway.
The woman takes one last look at the hallway, and then turns around and walks away.
FADE OUT.</s>

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A woman is swimming in a pool when suddenly a man in a wet suit attacks her and pulls her down. She is fighting for her life, but the man manages to overpower her completely.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and long enough.
response:
Title: Dark Waters
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
The camera pans across the backyard of a suburban house, showing a pool, a large house and a garden. The camera focuses on a woman in her mid-thirties swimming laps in the pool. She wears a bikini and looks strong and determined. She swims a few laps and gets tired. She stops and rests her hands on the edge of the pool, catching her breath.
The woman's name is Sarah. She is a single mother and a high school teacher. She is very disciplined and never takes a day off from her routine. She has been swimming every day for the past few months. It is her way to clear her mind and relax.
Her only company during her workouts is her friend, Mrs. Thompson, who sits on her porch, watching her swim. She has been doing this for the past three months, and they have formed a bond. Mrs. Thompson has been a mother figure to Sarah since her parents passed away when she was nineteen.
Suddenly, the pool's water begins to bubble, and a man in a wet suit emerges from the pool. He is wearing dark sunglasses, a mask and a black t-shirt. He grabs Sarah and pulls her under the water. She struggles, trying to break free, but he is too strong.
He pulls her down and holds her under the water for a few seconds until she can no longer breathe. She gasps for air, but he holds her down again. This cycle repeats a few more times. Sarah is fighting for her life.
Suddenly, Mrs. Thompson screams, "Sarah! Are you okay?" Sarah tries to speak, but she is struggling to breathe. She turns around, and Mrs. Thompson is gone! She jumps out of the pool and looks around. She sees the pool's surface and realizes that Mrs. Thompson is in the water, trying to save her.
She jumps back in the pool and grabs Mrs. Thompson's hand. Sarah looks at her friend, and she is already dead. She starts to cry, and the man in the wet suit grabs her again.
She fights him again, but he is too strong. He drags her under the water and holds her down this time. She is about to lose consciousness when she sees a flash of light. It's the police. They have arrived. Two officers jump into the pool and pull her out.
"Sarah, are you okay?" one of the officers asks her. She nods.
The police arrest the man in the wet suit, and they take Sarah to the hospital. She is shaken but okay. She has a few bruises, but nothing serious.
The police question her about what happened, and she tells them everything. She tells them about Mrs. Thompson's help and how she saved her life.
The police are amazed. They say that this man has been attacking people in the neighborhood for the past few months. They have no idea who he is. They take her statement and leave.
Sarah goes home, and the officer who was with her at the pool follows her. She thanks him and goes inside her house. She wants to go to bed, but she can't. She is too shaken. She spends the rest of the night replaying the incident in her head.
The next day, Sarah goes to school to teach her class. She is still shaken, but she is determined to move on. She doesn't want this incident to affect her life. She wants to live her life as normal as possible, but she can't. She keeps thinking about what happened, and she feels scared.
She can't sleep at night, and she can't concentrate on her work. She goes to her boss, and she tells her what happened. She explains that she can't teach anymore, and she needs time off. Her boss agrees, and she goes home.
Sarah spends the rest of the week in her house, trying to recover. She doesn't leave the house, and she doesn't go swimming. She can't stand the thought of being in the water again. She feels like she can't trust anyone anymore. Her life is in shambles.
One day, while she is going through her mail, she sees a letter from the police. It's her statement. She reads it, and she sees that the police have found the man in the wet suit. He is currently in jail, and they are waiting for him to come to trial.
Sarah feels relieved. She feels like she can trust the police now. She thinks that maybe she can move on. Maybe she can get back to her life.
Sarah goes to the trial. She sees the man in the wet suit. He looks at her, and she looks at him. She feels scared. The trial is over quickly, and the man in the wet suit is sentenced to life in prison. Sarah feels relieved and happy. She can finally move on with her life.
The next day, Sarah goes back to her job. She is happy to be back. She thinks that everything is going to be okay. She feels like she can trust people again. She feels like she can be happy again.
The same night that the trial is over, Sarah goes to sleep. She is tired and wants to forget about everything that has happened. She falls asleep quickly, and she has a dream. She dreams that someone is trying to strangle her. She wakes up with a start, and she is sweating. She looks around, and she sees the man in the wet suit.
She screams, and he runs away. She wakes up, and she is shaking. She looks around, and she sees that she is in her bed. She looks outside, and she sees that everything is okay. She thinks that she has had a bad dream, and she goes back to sleep.
The next day, Sarah goes to work. She is tired but wants to keep going. She thinks that everything is going to be okay. She is mistaken.
When she gets to work, she realizes that everything is different. Her class is different. Her students are different. Her boss is different. She feels like she is in a different world.
She goes to her classroom, and she sees that her students are not the same. They are different. They are hostile and don't respect her authority. They refuse to listen to her. She is scared.
She goes to her boss and tells her what happened. Her boss tells her that she is going to have to take a leave of absence. Sarah feels like her world is falling apart. She doesn't know what to do.
She goes home and stays there for a few days. She can't stand to be around people. She can't stand to be around herself. She feels like she is going crazy.
One day, Sarah goes to her local shop. She is trying to buy something to eat, but she can't focus on what she is doing. She is thinking about what happened to her and how she can move on.
She sees the man in the wet suit. He is standing in front of her. He looks at her, and she looks at him. She feels scared. The man in the wet suit starts to walk towards her, and she starts to run. She runs as fast as she can.
She runs out of the shop, and she sees that the man in the wet suit is chasing her. She runs as fast as she can, but he is too fast. He grabs her, and she falls to the ground. She struggles, but he is too strong. He holds her down, and she can't escape.
She looks at the man in the wet suit, and she sees his face. She recognizes him. She realizes that he is the man who killed her parents.
He looks at her, and she looks at him. She feels scared. She feels like she is going to die.
She starts to cry, and he starts to cry. He tells her that he is sorry. He tells her that he didn't mean to hurt her. She listens to him, and she knows that he is telling the truth.
She looks at him, and she forgives him. She tells him that she forgives him. She tells him that she loves him. He nods and wipes his tears. He tells her that he loves her too.
They hold each other, and they cry. They cry for a long time. They cry until they fall asleep.
They wake up, and they don't remember what happened. They are confused. They look at each other, and they know that they have a future together. They know that they will be happy.
The man in the wet suit takes off his mask and his sunglasses. He gives them to her. She puts them on and looks at him. She smiles. She loves him.
They get up and go home. They go to bed, and they fall asleep in each other's arms. They feel happy. They feel complete.
The next day, they wake up and go to work. They are happy to be together. They are happy to be alive. They are happy to have each other.</s>

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A helicopter is hovering above a snowy mountain top where some hikers got lost.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and long enough.
response:
Title: Lost in the Mountains
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
A man, RYAN (30s), sits in front of a fireplace, holding a map. He is worried.
RYAN
(to himself)
Where could they be? I must find them.
Ryan stands up and goes to the phone, dialing a number.
RYAN
(into phone)
Hello, is this the search and rescue team? I need your help.
EXT. HELICOPTER - DAY
A helicopter lands on a snowy mountain top. A man, MIKE (40s), and a woman, JEN (20s), get out of the helicopter.
MIKE
(looking around)
This place looks like a maze.
They start to search the mountain top.
JEN
(to Mike)
What on earth were they thinking? Going out on a hike in this weather?
MIKE
I don’t know. People are crazy.
They find a set of footprints in the snow.
MIKE
(looking at the footprints)
This is bad. These footprints look like they’ve been here for days.
They continue to search the mountain as the sun begins to set.
EXT. HELICOPTER - NIGHT
The helicopter is searching for them in the darkness. They finally spot a set of footprints in the snow.
MIKE
(into phone)
We found them.
EXT. SNOWY MOUNTAIN TOP - NIGHT
The helicopter hovering above a group of hikers.
MIKE
(into phone)
We found them.
RYAN
(into phone)
Good. Get them out of there.
EXT. SNOWY MOUNTAIN TOP - NIGHT
The helicopter is taking off with the hikers hanging from the side.
RYAN
(to himself)
Thank God.
The helicopter takes off and flies away as the camera pans out.
FADE OUT.
THE END.</s>

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A trial scene. The setting is a courtroom. The defense attorney is cross-examining the witness. The scene is emotional because the attorney manages to get the truth from the witness that exonerates her client.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and long enough.
response:
Title: The Truth Revealed
Slugline: INT. COURTHOUSE - DAY
The camera pans over a crowd of anxious spectators in the crowded courtroom. The camera focuses on the jury, the judge, and the defense attorney and prosecution team. The camera finally settles on the defendant, a woman in her thirties with short brown hair and a sad expression, seated at the defendant's table.
The judge is seated behind a raised platform, dressed in a black robe. The judge looks stern and authoritative, and the camera zooms in on the judge's face as he clears his throat and raps his gavel on the table.
"The courtroom is now in session," the judge says authoritatively. "We will begin with the prosecution."
The prosecutor, a man in his forties with a stern expression, stands and addresses the judge. "Your Honor, the prosecution rests its case."
The judge nods and turns to the defense attorney. "The defense may call its first witness."
The defense attorney, a woman in her forties with short blonde hair and a confident expression, stands and addresses the judge. "Your Honor, the defense calls our first witness, Jane Smith."
Jane Smith, a woman in her fifties with graying hair and a sad expression, stands and walks to the witness stand.
The judge nods and addresses Jane. "Miss Smith, please raise your right hand and swear to tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, so help you God."
Jane raises her hand and looks at the judge. "I do."
The judge nods and calls the defense attorney to examine Jane. The defense attorney walks to the witness stand and begins questioning Jane.
"Miss Smith, when did you first meet my client, Ms. Johnson?"
"I first met Ms. Johnson about two years ago," Jane says, her voice shaking. "She was looking for a job, and I hired her to work in my store."
"And how long did Ms. Johnson work for you?"
"She worked for me for about six months. She was a good worker, but she had some problems with her personal life."
"Such as?"
"She had a drinking problem and she had some trouble with the law. She was arrested for DWI a few times."
"And did that affect her performance?"
"No, she was always on time for work and she always did what I asked of her."
"So why did she leave your employment?"
"She was fired," Jane says, her voice shaking. "She had been drinking at work, and I had to let her go."
"And you fired her without giving her a chance to explain?"
Jane nods and begins to cry. "I'm sorry, I just can't talk about it."
The defense attorney nods and begins to question Jane about the night of the incident. "Miss Smith, you were at the bar the night that Ms. Johnson was arrested, correct?"
Jane nods and begins to cry. "Yes, I was."
"What were you doing at the bar?"
"I was meeting with some friends for a girls' night out," Jane says, still crying. "We were just having a good time, and then the police came in and arrested Ms. Johnson."
"And you didn't see her leave the bar?"
Jane shakes her head and begins to cry. "No, I didn't. I didn't even see her leave the bar. I just heard the commotion and looked up and saw the police taking her away."
The defense attorney nods and begins to question Jane about the events leading up to the incident. "Miss Smith, you said that Ms. Johnson had a drinking problem. Do you know how much she had to drink the night of the incident?"
"She had been drinking all day, and she was very drunk when she got to the bar," Jane says, still crying. "She was throwing up in the bathroom and she was falling all over the place."
"And did you see her drink anything else after she got to the bar?"
"I don't know," Jane says, still crying. "I was in the bathroom when she ordered another drink, and I didn't see her drink it."
The defense attorney nods and begins to question Jane about the events of the night of the incident. "Miss Smith, you said that you didn't see Ms. Johnson leave the bar. Do you know who she left with?"
"No, I don't," Jane says, still crying. "I just saw her being arrested, and then I went home."
The defense attorney nods and turns to the judge. "Your Honor, no further questions."
The judge nods and turns to the prosecutor. "Prosecution, cross-examination."
The prosecutor stands and begins to question Jane. "Miss Smith, you said that you were at the bar the night of the incident. Is that true?"
"Yes, it is," Jane says, still crying. "I was there with my friends, having a good time."
"And do you remember seeing Ms. Johnson at the bar that night?"
"Yes, I remember seeing her," Jane says, still crying. "She was very drunk, and she was causing a lot of trouble."
"And did you see her leave the bar?"
"No, I didn't," Jane says, still crying. "I didn't even see her leave the bar. I just heard the commotion and looked up and saw the police taking her away."
"And you didn't see who she left with?"
"No, I didn't," Jane says, still crying. "I just saw her being arrested, and then I went home."
The prosecutor nods and turns to the judge. "No further questions, Your Honor."
The judge nods and turns to the defense attorney. "Defense, re-examination."
The defense attorney stands and begins to question Jane. "Miss Smith, you said that you were at the bar the night of the incident. Is that true?"
"Yes, it is," Jane says, still crying. "I was there with my friends, having a good time."
"And do you remember seeing Ms. Johnson at the bar that night?"
"Yes, I remember seeing her," Jane says, still crying. "She was very drunk, and she was causing a lot of trouble."
"And did you see her leave the bar?"
"No, I didn't," Jane says, still crying. "I didn't even see her leave the bar. I just heard the commotion and looked up and saw the police taking her away."

"No, I didn't," Jane says, still crying. "I just saw her being arrested, and then I went home."

A woman, SARAH, in her 30s, runs out of the house in a panic, covered in blood. She's screaming for help.
Her neighbors rush out, some of them carrying weapons. They form a circle around her.
SARAH (crying): Someone broke in and killed my husband!
NEIGHBOR 1: What happened?
SARAH (still crying): I don't know! He was asleep in bed, and suddenly I heard a loud noise. I went to see what it was, and I saw a man in a mask with a knife, stabbing my husband! I called 911, but I don't think they're coming!
NEIGHBOR 2: We'll wait with you until they get here.
SARAH (nodding): Thank you.
NEIGHBOR 1 (pulling out his cell phone): I'm going to call the police again.

NEIGHBOR 1: Are you sure?

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A man takes up dancing because his wife used to beg him to do that. After her sudden death, he decides to honor her wish. The new chapter in his life promises new love.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and long enough.
response:
Title: Dancing Through Grief
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
A dark house, lit only by the soft glow of a television. The sound of a man's muffled sobs can be heard from the living room. He's sitting on the couch with a glass of wine in his hand. He looks mournfully at a photo of him and his wife on the coffee table. He glances at the alarm clock. It's 11:00 pm. He takes a long gulp of wine and puts down the glass. He gets up and walks to the couch. He takes the photo and places it down on the bedside table. He turns off the lights and walks away, leaving the door slightly ajar.
EXT. DANCING SCHOOL - DAY
A bright, sunny day. Birds are chirping and children are playing in the park. The camera focuses on a dancing school. The sign on the building says "Ballroom Dancing." A man is sitting in his car, parked across the street. He's staring at the building, his eyes wide with shock. He looks down at his phone and reads a message from his wife. "Please take dance classes. I've always wanted to dance with you." The man looks up at the school and sighs. He puts his phone down and starts the car. He drives away.
INT. DANCING SCHOOL - DAY
A dance instructor is practicing with a student. The student looks frustrated and angry. The instructor is trying to help her, but she keeps messing up. The instructor is getting annoyed. Suddenly, the man from earlier walks in. The instructor looks up and sees him. He looks determined. He walks to the front of the studio and asks to speak to the owner. The instructor stops dancing with the student. He walks to the owner's office and knocks on the door.
DANCING INSTRUCTOR
Good afternoon, sir. What can I do for you?
MAN
I'd like to speak to the owner.
DANCING INSTRUCTOR
I'm sorry, sir, but the owner is not here at the moment.
MAN
Can you give him this message?
DANCING INSTRUCTOR
I'm sorry, sir, but I don't have his phone number.
MAN
(sighs)
Fine. I'll just leave it here.
The man hands the instructor an envelope. The instructor opens it and reads the message inside. He looks at the man and says, "I'm sorry, sir. I can't help you."
MAN
(angrily)
I just want to dance. Is that too much to ask?
DANCING INSTRUCTOR
(sighs)
Sir, I understand. But you can't just be a beginner. You have to know how to dance. That's why I'm offering to give you a free lesson.
MAN
(suspiciously)
Why would you do that?
DANCING INSTRUCTOR
Because I'm a professional. My job is to teach people how to dance. I know you can do it, sir. All you need is a little bit of help.
MAN
(thoughtfully)
Okay. I'll take you up on your offer.
The instructor smiles and shakes the man's hand.
DANCING INSTRUCTOR
Great! Follow me, please.
The instructor leads the man to a small room.
INT. DANCING STUDIO - DAY
The instructor and the man are standing in the middle of the room. The music is playing softly in the background. The instructor begins to dance. He's moving in rhythm with the music. He's smiling and laughing as he dances. The man watches him in awe.
DANCING INSTRUCTOR
(smiling)
You see how easy it is, sir? You just need to relax and have fun.
The man nods and begins to dance.
DANCING INSTRUCTOR
(laughing)
See? You're almost as good as me.
The man laughs as he continues to dance.
DANCING INSTRUCTOR
(smiling)
I'm not kidding, sir. You could be a great dancer.
The man stops dancing and looks at the instructor.
MAN
(sighs)
I wish.
DANCING INSTRUCTOR
(smiling)
Why don't you try again, sir? I'm sure you'll do better this time.
The man smiles and begins to dance again.
EXT. PARK - DAY
A park, filled with people. A man is sitting on a bench, staring at a photo of him and his wife. He looks sad and lonely. He looks up and sees a woman walking towards him. He stands up and walks over to her.
WOMAN
Hi. I'm Maria.
MAN
(smiling)
Hi. I'm Tom.
Maria smiles and sits down next to Tom.
MARIA
What are you doing here?
TOM
(sighs)
I was just thinking about her.
MARIA
(sadly)
I know the feeling.
TOM
(surprised)
You? I'm sorry. I didn't mean to…
MARIA
(smiling)
It's okay. I lost my husband a few months ago. He was always taking care of me. I was lost without him.
TOM
(sadly)
I know how you feel. My wife passed away a few months ago. She was always telling me to take dancing classes. I never listened to her. I wish I had.
MARIA
(smiling)
Maybe it's not too late.
TOM
(surprised)
What do you mean?
MARIA
(smiling)
I hear there's a great dancing school down the street. Maybe you can take some classes and learn how to dance.
TOM
(smiling)
Maybe I will.
MARIA
(smiling)
I have a feeling you're going to love it.
TOM
(smiling)
I think you're right. I'm going to go there tomorrow.
MARIA
(smiling)
That's great, Tom. I'm happy for you.
Tom smiles and gets up. He walks over to Maria and gives her a hug.
TOM
Thank you. I really appreciate this.
MARIA
(smiling)
You're welcome. I'm glad I could help you.
Tom walks away and Maria smiles after him.
INT. DANCING SCHOOL - DAY
A dance instructor is giving a lesson to a group of students. The man from earlier is in the back, watching the instructor and the students. A girl walks into the room. The man looks up and sees her. He stands up and walks over to her.
MAN
(smiling)
Hi. I was just wondering if I could talk to you for a minute.
GIRL
(smiling)
Of course. I'm not busy.
The man looks at the girl and says, "I'm Tom."
GIRL
(smiling)
Hi, Tom. I'm Maria.
Tom smiles and says, "I'm sorry to bother you, but I was wondering if you could help me. I was thinking about taking dance classes, but I don't know where to start."
MARIA
(smiling)
No problem, Tom. I'll be happy to help you. Do you want to take beginner classes?
TOM
(smiling)
Yes, please. I've never danced before.
MARIA
(smiling)
That's okay, Tom. I can teach you.
Tom smiles and says, "Thank you. I really appreciate it."
MARIA
(smiling)
No problem. I'll see you tomorrow at 7:00 pm.
Tom smiles and nods. He walks away and Maria smiles after him.
EXT. DANCING SCHOOL - DAY
The man from earlier is sitting in his car, parked across the street. He's staring at the dancing school. He looks down at his phone and reads a message from his wife. "Please take dance classes. I've always wanted to dance with you." The man looks up at the school and sighs. He puts his phone down and starts the car. He drives away.

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A woman is walking her pet in the park. At one point, she drops the leash, and the dog finds a friend in the park. The woman makes a witty remark, which prompts a pleasant conversation between her and a handsome man. He asks for her number so that they could go on a date.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and long enough.
response:
Title: "Unleashed Love"
INT. PARK - DAY
A woman, LUCY, in her mid-thirties with long, blonde hair, walks her dog, MAX, through the park. She has on a blue sweatshirt, jeans, and running shoes. Max is a large, fluffy golden retriever. Lucy is talking on her cell phone.
LUCY
I'm sorry, I can't make it tomorrow. I have to take Max to the vet.
She hangs up the phone and looks down at Max.
LUCY (CONT'D)
You're lucky the vet doesn't make us wear masks.
Max barks.
LUCY (CONT'D)
Yes, I know, we'll get there eventually.
Max tugs at the leash and Lucy lets go, allowing him to run to a nearby tree. Lucy follows and watches as Max sniffs the tree.
LUCY (CONT'D)
I'll go ahead and give him the treats before we get there.
Lucy pulls a small bag of dog treats from her pocket and pours some out for Max.
MAX
Lucy looks at Max's full bowl and smiles.
LUCY (CONT'D)
You're such a good boy.
Lucy continues to walk around the park as Max sniffs everything in sight.
LUCY (CONT'D)
Max, come on.
Lucy looks around for Max and realizes that he's gone.
LUCY (CONT'D)
Max?
Lucy looks around and sees Max playing with another dog.
LUCY (CONT'D)
Max, come here!
Max barks and runs towards Lucy.
LUCY (CONT'D)
Good boy.
LUCY (CONT'D)
Oh, thank God.
Lucy looks at her watch.
LUCY (CONT'D)
I'm going to be late.
Lucy starts to walk away, but Max pulls on the leash.
LUCY (CONT'D)
Yes, I know you want to play.
Max barks.
LUCY (CONT'D)
Okay, we can play a little longer.
They continue to walk through the park as Max sniffs and plays with other dogs.
LUCY (CONT'D)
I'm so sorry. I forgot to bring your ball.
Lucy looks down at Max and smiles.
LUCY (CONT'D)
But I'll get you one tomorrow.
Lucy continues to walk and talks with other dog owners.
LUCY (CONT'D)
It's always fun to take him to the park, but he does get too excited sometimes.
She walks over to a group of people with their dogs.
LUCY (CONT'D)
He's like a little kid and we can never keep up with him.
A handsome man, JOHN, in his mid-thirties with short, dark hair and green eyes, looks over at Lucy.
LUCY (CONT'D)
Yeah, he's a handful, but I wouldn't trade him for the world.
John smiles at her.
JOHN
He seems like a really good boy.
John looks down at his own dog, a small, fluffy white dog.
JOHN (CONT'D)
I'm sorry, I didn't catch your name.
LUCY
Lucy.
John extends his hand.
JOHN (CONT'D)
Nice to meet you, Lucy. I'm John.
LUCY
It's nice to meet you too.
They continue to talk about their dogs.
LUCY (CONT'D)
My husband and I have been trying to get him to settle down.
JOHN
You have a husband?
LUCY
Yes, we've been married for about five years now.
John looks at Lucy and smiles.
JOHN (CONT'D)
That's great.
LUCY (CONT'D)
We're just trying to decide if we want to get another one.
JOHN
I'm guessing you have your hands full with Max.
John laughs.
LUCY
Yes, he's a handful.
Max barks and runs over to John.
JOHN
Hi, there.
Max jumps up and licks John's face.
LUCY
Oh, Max, I'm sorry.
Lucy looks at Max and smiles.
LUCY (CONT'D)
That's okay. He always has to meet everyone.
John reaches down and pets Max's head.
JOHN (CONT'D)
He's a very friendly dog.
LUCY
Yes, he is.
Max sits next to John and looks up at him.
LUCY (CONT'D)
Well, I should get going.
They stand up and start to walk away.
LUCY (CONT'D)
It was nice meeting you, John.
JOHN
It was nice meeting you too, Lucy.
Lucy looks back at John and smiles.
LUCY (CONT'D)
Oh, I almost forgot.
Lucy pulls out a piece of paper and a pen from her pocket.
LUCY (CONT'D)
Here's my number.
She hands him the paper.
LUCY (CONT'D)
In case you want to take Max out sometime.
John looks at the paper.
JOHN (CONT'D)
I'd like that.
John smiles at her.
LUCY (CONT'D)
I'll give you a call.
John looks at Lucy and smiles.
Lucy and Max start to walk away, but Max stops and runs back to John.
LUCY
Max, what are you doing?
Max jumps up and licks John's face again.
LUCY (CONT'D)
Sorry again.
John smiles at Lucy.
JOHN
It's okay.
LUCY
Bye.
Lucy and Max walk away.
John looks after them.
Max sits down next to John and looks up at him.
John smiles at Max.
JOHN
You're a good boy.
John looks at Max and smiles.
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
Lucy and her husband, MIKE, sit on the couch in their living room.
LUCY
He was so cute. That's the first time he's ever done that.
MIKE
You mean, jump up and lick the guy?
Lucy looks at Mike.
LUCY
No, give me his number.
Mike looks at her.
MIKE
What?
LUCY
I gave him my number.
Mike looks at Lucy.
MIKE
Why?
LUCY
I don't know, he seemed nice.
MIKE
Lucy, we've been married for five years.
LUCY
I know, but he seemed nice.
MIKE
I don't think you're thinking this through.
LUCY
I know, I'm sorry.
Lucy looks down.
MIKE
You don't need to apologize.
Lucy looks up at Mike.
LUCY
I know.
They sit in silence for a moment.
LUCY (CONT'D)
I just...I don't know.
Mike looks at Lucy.
MIKE
Lucy, you don't need to go out and find someone else.
LUCY
I know, I know. I just...
Mike gets up and walks over to Lucy.
MIKE
I'm sorry, I didn't mean to be rude.
LUCY
It's okay.
Mike sits down next to Lucy and puts his arm around her.
MIKE (CONT'D)
I just want you to be happy.
LUCY
I know.
They sit in silence for a moment.
LUCY (CONT'D)
I just feel like maybe I need to do something besides take care of Max and work.
Mike looks at Lucy.
MIKE
You like your job.
LUCY
I know, but it's not the same as being with other people.
MIKE
You're not alone. We're always together.
LUCY
I know, but it's not the same as being with other people.
Mike looks at Lucy.
MIKE
I don't want you to go out and meet someone else.
LUCY
I know, I know.
Mike looks at Lucy.
MIKE
I just want you to be happy.
LUCY
I know.
They sit in silence for a moment.
MIKE (CONT'D)
Why don't you try going to a dog park?
LUCY
I know, but what if I meet someone and they don't like dogs?
MIKE
Then they're not the one for you.
LUCY
I guess you're right.
LUCY (CONT'D)
I'm sorry.
MIKE
Don't be sorry.
They sit in silence for a moment.
MIKE (CONT'D)
What if you went to the dog park and you met someone and you hit it off?
LUCY
I know, but what if they're not the one for me?
MIKE
Then you'll know it's not going to work out.
LUCY
I know.
They sit in silence for a moment.
LUCY (CONT'D)
I'll go to the dog park tomorrow.
Mike looks at Lucy.
MIKE
Okay.
They sit in silence for a moment.
MIKE (CONT'D)
I love you, Lucy.
LUCY
I love you too.
They kiss and hug.
LUCY (CONT'D)
I'm sorry.
MIKE
Don't be sorry.
They sit in silence for a moment.
MIKE (CONT'D)
You just want to meet new people.
LUCY
I know, I know.
They sit in silence for a moment.
MIKE (CONT'D)
I'm going to bed.
LUCY
Okay.
They sit in silence for a moment.
LUCY (CONT'D)
Goodnight.
MIKE
Goodnight.
Lucy gets up and walks over to Mike.
LUCY (CONT'D)
I love you.
LUCY (CONT'D)
I'll see you in the morning.
LUCY walks out of the room.

LUCY
Max, where are you?
She walks over to a group of people with their dogs.
LUCY
Excuse me, does anyone know where the dog park is?

LUCY
Hi.
SARAH
Hi. I'm Sarah.

This is Max.

SARAH
Hi, Max.

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: Many people are attending a funeral. The police are also present at the cemetery.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and long enough.
response:
Title: A Life Remembrance
Slugline: EXTERIOR - CEMETERY - NIGHT
EXT. CEMETERY - NIGHT
A dark and gloomy night. The cemetery is lit up by the moon. The only sound is that of the breeze moving through the trees. A hearse approaches the cemetery, followed by multiple cars. Police vehicles are also present.
The cars stop, and the attendees of the funeral exit the vehicles. They all head towards the hearse, which stops in front of an open grave. The door of the hearse opens, and the casket comes out. It is carried towards the grave.
The mourners gather around the grave, and the priest begins the service. The priest speaks about the deceased's life, achievements, and good deeds. The mourners listen attentively, and some of them shed tears.
A young man steps forward and speaks to the priest. He identifies himself as the deceased's son. He remembers his father's good deeds and how much he loved him. He thanks the priest for the kind words and for conducting the service.
The priest then turns to the mourners and asks them to pray for the deceased. The mourners bow their heads, and the priest leads them in prayer.
After the prayer, the priest asks the mourners to close their eyes and remember the deceased. He then tells them that the deceased has been taken to heaven by God's grace.
Slugline: EXTERIOR - CEMETERY - DAY
EXT. CEMETERY - DAY
The next day, the cemetery is crowded with people. Some are looking for a place to park. A woman walks towards the grave and stops. She looks at the grave and then turns towards the camera.
Slugline: INT. PRIEST'S OFFICE - DAY
INT. PRIEST'S OFFICE - DAY
The priest is sitting at his desk, reading a book. The woman knocks on the door and enters. She walks towards the priest and sits down.
WOMAN: Father, I came to talk to you.
The priest puts down the book and looks at her.
PRIEST: Of course, my child. What can I do for you?
WOMAN: Father, I am the mother of the deceased.
PRIEST: I'm sorry, but I cannot reveal that information. We need to maintain confidentiality.
WOMAN: I'm not asking for his name. I wanted to talk to you about the funeral.
The priest looks at her.
PRIEST: How can I help you?
WOMAN: My husband and I have been married for 35 years. Our son was our only child. We never forgot to pray for him every day. We raised him to be a good man. He was a good man.
The woman stops and then continues.
WOMAN: Father, when I came here yesterday, I saw people I never saw before. I do not know who they are. They did not even know my son.
The priest looks at her.
PRIEST: What do you want me to do?
The woman looks at him.
WOMAN: Father, you know what I want you to do. Please tell me who these people are.
The priest looks at her and then thinks for a while.
PRIEST: My child, I cannot reveal that information. But I can assure you that they were invited by the deceased.
The woman looks at him.
WOMAN: Father, I do not understand. How did you know that these people were invited by my son?
The priest looks at her and then leans forward.
PRIEST: My child, I saw your son yesterday. He came to the funeral.
The woman looks at him.
WOMAN: Father, are you crazy? How can you say that? My son is dead.
The priest looks at her.
PRIEST: My child, I am not crazy. I saw your son. He told me to come and talk to you.
The woman looks at him.
WOMAN: What did he say to you?
The priest looks at her and then thinks for a while.
PRIEST: He said that he was sorry.
The woman looks at him.
WOMAN: Sorry? What does he mean?
The priest looks at her.
PRIEST: He said that he was sorry for not being a good son. He said that he was sorry for not listening to us. He said that he was sorry for everything.
The woman looks at him.
WOMAN: Father, what does he mean? What did you do to him?
The priest looks at her.
PRIEST: My child, I did not do anything to your son. He loved you very much.
The woman looks at him.
WOMAN: What are you talking about? How do you know all this?
The priest looks at her and then leans forward.
PRIEST: My child, I am a priest. I am a spiritual leader. I knew your son from the day he was born. You and your husband came to me every week for confession. I know everything about your son.
The woman looks at him.
WOMAN: Father, I do not understand. What did you do to my son?
The priest looks at her.
PRIEST: My child, I did not do anything to your son. He was a good man. He was a man of God. He loved you very much.

PRIEST: My child, I am a priest. I am a spiritual leader. I knew your son from the day he was born. You and your husband came to me every week for confession. I know everything about your son.

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A math teacher calls the parents of a gifted boy to suggest a more advanced curriculum.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and long enough.
response:
Title: The Bright Spark
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
The camera pans over the front porch of a suburban home. The sound of leaves crunching under footsteps can be heard. A man, MR. WESTWOOD, opens the front door and steps out onto the porch. He takes a deep breath of the cool autumn air and glances at the stars. He smiles and shakes his head.
MR. WESTWOOD (MID-30S, tall, muscular. He wears glasses and carries a briefcase.)
This kid is just...
The camera zooms in on Mr. Westwood’s face. The light from the porch illuminates him, but his features are obscured by the shadows.
He continues, “He's going to make me look like a genius.”
The camera pans down to reveal a small, brown dog that is sitting at Mr. Westwood’s feet.
MR. WESTWOOD
(Laughs)
“I'd better get moving, or I'll miss my bedtime.”
The camera stops, and the scene goes to black.
INT. HIGH SCHOOL - DAY
A bell rings, and the camera pans over a sea of desks. A young boy, JASON (12), is sitting in the front row of the classroom. He is writing in a notebook, and his pencil is moving rapidly. The teacher, Ms. GILDED, enters the classroom. She walks to the front of the class and addresses the students.
MS. GILDED (40s, attractive, poised. She has a no-nonsense attitude.)
“Okay, class. Today we're going to learn about the Pythagorean theorem. Does anyone know what that is?”
Jason raises his hand and looks around the room, hoping someone else will volunteer. No one does. He reluctantly puts his hand down.
MS. GILDED
“Jason, did you want to tell us about the Pythagorean theorem?”
Jason blushes and looks down at his notebook. He shakes his head.
MS. GILDED
“Come on. It's no big deal. You've got it all figured out, right?”
Jason nods.
MS. GILDED
“Then why don't you share your thoughts with the class?”
Jason looks around the room again, then sighs. He raises his hand.
MS. GILDED
“Jason.”
Jason stands up and walks to the front of the class. He stands in front of the chalkboard and begins to speak.
JASON
(12, thin, with a mop of dark hair. He has a shy smile and a nervous energy about him.)
“Well, um, the Pythagorean theorem is a mathematical formula that...”
MR. WESTWOOD (V.O.)
Oh my God.
The camera zooms in on Mr. Westwood, who is sitting in the back of the classroom. He is smiling and looking at Jason with pride. His eyes are watery, and he is wiping them with a handkerchief.
JASON (V.O.)
...It tells you how long the sides of a right triangle are. It says that the square of the length of the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides.
MR. WESTWOOD (V.O.)
He's got it...
The camera continues to zoom in on Mr. Westwood, until he fills the entire screen.
MS. GILDED
Jason! You're quite the math whiz, aren't you?
Jason smiles and nods.
MS. GILDED
I'm surprised that a student your age is already able to understand such a complex concept.
Jason looks at the floor and shuffles his feet. He mumbles something inaudible.
MS. GILDED
What was that?
Jason looks up and speaks more clearly.
JASON
I'm sorry, Miss Gilded. I just want to say that I don't think I really understand this theorem.
MR. WESTWOOD (V.O.)
No! No, no, no.
The camera zooms back out to show the rest of the classroom. Ms. Gilded is stunned, and the other students are looking at Jason with surprise.
MS. GILDED
Oh, Jason, don't be silly. You're a genius. You're much too smart to be wasting your time in my classroom.
MR. WESTWOOD (V.O.)
This is it...
MS. GILDED
I'm going to have to ask you to leave my class. You're much too advanced for my curriculum.
Jason is confused and begins to look around the room. He sees Ms. Gilded coming towards him with a folder in her hand.
JASON
(Starts to back away)
Miss Gilded, please. I don't want to leave.
MS. GILDED
This is for your own good, Jason. You belong in a gifted program. You simply don't need to be wasting your time with the rest of these students.
Jason begins to cry. He turns and runs out of the classroom, with Ms. Gilded chasing after him.
EXT. HOME - DAY
Mr. Westwood is walking through the front door of his house, carrying a book bag. His wife, DR. WESTWOOD (30s, pretty, kind-hearted), is sitting in the living room, reading a magazine. She looks up as Mr. Westwood enters the room.
DR. WESTWOOD
How was school?
MR. WESTWOOD
School was fine. I'm just glad to be home.
Jason runs into the room, sobbing.
JASON
Daddy, Miss Gilded said I have to leave her class.
Dr. Westwood stands up and walks over to her son. She kneels down in front of him and hugs him.
DR. WESTWOOD
Oh, sweetie. It's going to be okay. I promise.
MR. WESTWOOD
(Looks at Dr. Westwood)
You don't understand. This is it. This is the moment that we've been waiting for.
Jason looks up at his father.
MR. WESTWOOD
(Laughs)
You're going to be a genius!
Jason looks confused.
DR. WESTWOOD
(Looks at her husband)
What?
MR. WESTWOOD
(Stands up)
The school is going to call us tonight. They're going to suggest that Jason be placed in an advanced curriculum.
Jason's eyes light up.
DR. WESTWOOD
(Looks at her husband)
What?
Jason jumps up and wraps his arms around his father's legs.
JASON
Daddy, I'm going to be a genius!
MR. WESTWOOD
(Laughs)
I'm sorry, honey. I was just teasing you.
Jason looks at his father with disappointment.
MR. WESTWOOD
(Looks at his wife)
Really, though. You'll see. The school is going to call us tonight with the news.
Jason looks at his mother, who is smiling at him.
JASON
Mommy, will I still get to see my friends?
DR. WESTWOOD
Of course you will, sweetie. You can still hang out with your classmates. You just won't be taking their classes anymore.
Jason nods, and Mr. Westwood walks over to the phone. He dials the school.
INT. SCHOOL - DAY
A woman, MS. HOWELL (40s, stern, no-nonsense), is sitting at her desk, smoking a cigarette. She receives a call and answers it.
MS. HOWELL
(40s, stern, no-nonsense)
Yes, this is Ms. Howell. How may I help you?
MR. WESTWOOD
(V.O.)
Ms. Howell. This is Mr. Westwood from the Gifted Program at the high school. I'm calling about a boy named Jason.
MR. WESTWOOD (V.O.)
Oh, absolutely. I think he'd be perfect for our program. He's an incredibly bright child.

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A famous composer is shown in the creative process of composing a musical masterpiece.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and long enough.
response:
Title: The Symphony of a Lifetime
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
A soft, steady piano melody fills the air as we open on an empty, large, well-lit room, a single lamp on the piano in the center of the space. The piano is a worn, beautiful grand with a large music stand in front of it.
The sound of the piano swells, adding in more instruments as the camera moves to show ANNE, a woman in her 50s, sitting at the piano, lost in the creation of her new piano concerto.
The camera then pans left to show a closed door, marked with a “Do Not Enter” sign. The camera then moves to a shot of the outside of the house, then cuts to the front lawn.
EXT. LAWN - NIGHT
An old man, JASPER, sits on a bench, a violin in his lap. He bows the strings, playing an old melody. The camera then pans over to a second bench, where another woman, CAROLINE, sits, holding a harp. She is humming a melody.
The camera then moves back to Jasper, who looks over to Caroline. He nods his head, and the two begin to play their respective melodies together. The music moves out of the house and into the night.
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
Anne continues to play, her fingers expertly moving across the keys as the sound of the instruments grows louder and louder. The camera moves to show the music in the stand in front of the piano, which reads, “Piano Concerto No. 3.”
The camera then pans to the door behind Anne, which slowly opens to reveal LUCAS, a man in his late 30s. He is wearing a suit and tie, and he looks exhausted.
LUCAS
(to himself)
I have to ask her.
Anne turns around to look at him.
ANNE
What do you want, Lucas?
LUCAS
You need a break, Anne. You’re working too hard.
Anne smiles at him.
ANNE
I’m on a roll, Lucas. I’m finally getting somewhere with this piece. I don’t want to stop.
Lucas shakes his head and lets out a sigh.
LUCAS
I understand, but you need to take care of yourself. You can’t keep working like this. You have to take a break.
Anne stands up and moves to the door, where she grabs her coat.
ANNE
I’m not tired, Lucas. Please leave.
Lucas nods and gets up to follow her.
INT. LIVING ROOM - NIGHT
Anne and Lucas sit on the couch together, staring at each other in silence.
LUCAS
You’re going to make yourself sick, Anne. You need to relax.
Anne looks down at her hands, still holding the piano music.
ANNE
I know, Lucas. I just can’t stop.
Lucas stands up.
LUCAS
I’m going to go make some tea. Would you like some?
Anne nods her head.
ANNE
Yes, please. Thank you.
Lucas gets up and heads into the kitchen, and the door shuts behind him. Anne lets out a heavy sigh.
ANNE
(to herself)
I can’t stop. I have to finish this.
The camera shows her sitting on the couch, staring at the piano music in her lap, lost in thought.
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT
Lucas brings two mugs of tea into the living room, where Anne is still staring at the piano music in her lap. He hands her a mug and sits down next to her.
LUCAS
Here you go.
Anne looks up at him.
ANNE
Thanks.
They sit in silence for a few seconds, then Lucas speaks up.
LUCAS
You’re going to finish this, right?
Anne nods her head.
ANNE
I have to. I can’t stop now.
Lucas takes a sip of his tea.
LUCAS
You really don’t need to push yourself so hard. You’ve already done so much. You’re famous, Anne. People love you.
Anne looks down at her tea.
ANNE
It’s not enough. I need to do more. I need to be better.
Lucas looks down at his tea.
LUCAS
I can see why you’re so ambitious, but you have to take care of yourself, too. You can’t do everything.
Anne looks up at him.
ANNE
But I want to. I have to.
Lucas leans forward and puts his hand on Anne’s knee.
LUCAS
It’s not healthy, Anne. You need to take care of yourself.
Anne looks away from him.
ANNE
I know, Lucas. But I can’t stop.
Lucas stands up and walks over to the piano. He sits down and looks at the piano music on the stand.
Lucas
(to himself)
She really is brilliant.
He picks up the music and starts to read it.
LUCAS
This is amazing.
He turns to Anne.
LUCAS
I know you didn’t mean to, but you really are brilliant.
Anne looks down at her tea.
ANNE
I know.
Lucas stands up and looks over at the piano.
LUCAS
I think I’m going to call it a night. I’m going to go to bed. You should, too.
Anne looks up at him.
ANNE
Maybe you’re right. I need to get some rest.
Lucas nods his head and heads out of the room. The door shuts behind him.
Anne looks down at her tea.
ANNE
I can’t stop. I have to finish this.
The camera shows a close-up of Anne’s hands, still holding the piano music. She starts to play the melody, her fingers moving expertly across the keys as the sound of the piano fills the room.
ANNE
(to herself)
This is my life’s work.
She smiles and closes her eyes, lost in the music.

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: Passengers on a plane start panicking when they learn that there is a serious problem with one of the engines. The flight attendants try to calm them down, but with little success. The plane starts falling and everybody starts screaming and praying.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and long enough.
response:
Title: Falling
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT:
A young family is sitting in their living room. The parents are sitting on the couch while their two kids are watching a movie.
DAD
Alright, guys, it's past your bedtime but I'm going to let you finish the movie.
The kids start jumping around in excitement.
The phone rings. The mom answers it.
MOM
Hello?
The dad looks at her with a questioning look.
MOM
(into the phone) No, nothing. What is it? (pauses) OK, I'll tell him. (pauses) Alright, I'll call you back. (hands the phone to her husband)
DAD
(answers the phone) Hello?
The camera slowly zooms in on the dad's face.
DEADLINE: 10 Pages
INT. AIRPORT - DAY:
The family is standing by the gate, waiting for the flight to be called. The parents are holding their children's hands.
MOM
(to the kids) Are you excited?
The kids nod. The family exchanges a quick hug.
DEADLINE: 20 PAGES
EXT. AIRPORT - DAY:
The plane is seen taxiing down the runway. The family watches it take off.
MOM
(to the kids) Bye, bye.
The kids wave goodbye to the plane.
DEADLINE: 30 PAGES
INT. PLANE - DAY:
The plane is in the air. The parents are trying to calm their children down.
MOM
(to her children) Alright, guys, it's time to nap.
The kids start to get sleepy.
DEADLINE: 40 PAGES
INT. PLANE - DAY (5 MINUTES LATER):
The plane is making strange noises. The kids are wide awake.
CHILD 1
(to his brother) Is that an explosion?
The parents look at each other in concern.
DEADLINE: 50 PAGES
INT. PLANE - DAY (2 MINUTES LATER):
The flight attendants are rushing through the cabin, making sure everyone is buckled up.
FATHER
(to the flight attendant) What's going on?
The flight attendant doesn't answer. She just looks at him.
DEADLINE: 60 PAGES
EXT. PLANE - DAY:
The plane is falling. The camera is showing the people on the ground watching the plane fall.
DEADLINE: 70 PAGES
INT. PLANE - DAY:
The plane is falling. The parents are holding the children.
MOTHER
(to her children) It's going to be OK. Daddy and I are here.
The children start to cry.
DEADLINE: 80 PAGES
INT. PLANE - DAY (5 MINUTES LATER):
The plane is about to crash. The children are crying and holding on to their parents.
CHILD 1
(to his brother) Daddy, it's going to hurt.
FATHER
(to his son) It's going to be OK.
The father starts to cry.
DEADLINE: 90 PAGES
INT. PLANE - DAY (1 MINUTE BEFORE THE PLANE CRASHES):
The plane is crashing. The children are screaming.
CHILD 2
(to his brother) I don't want to die.
FATHER
(to his children) It's going to be OK. Just stay calm.
The father starts to pray.
DEADLINE: 100 PAGES
EXT. PLANE - DAY:
The plane crashes.
DEADLINE: 110 PAGES
INT. PLANE - DAY (THE MOMENT THE PLANE CRASHES):
The family is safe. They are all alive. They are in shock.
FATHER
(to his wife) Are you OK?
MOM
(to her husband) Yes. (pauses) Are you OK?
FATHER
(to his wife) Yes. (pauses) Are the kids OK?
MOM
(to her husband) Yes.
The children start to cry.
FATHER
(to his children) It's going to be OK.
The family hugs each other.
DEADLINE: 120 PAGES
INT. HOSPITAL - DAY:
The family is sitting in a hospital room. The father is holding the children while the mother is sitting next to him.
MOM
(to her husband) Are they going to be OK?
FATHER
(to his wife) I don't know. They're going to be fine.
The family starts to cry.
DEADLINE: 130 PAGES
EXT. HOSPITAL - DAY:
The family is leaving the hospital. The family is walking out of the hospital, holding each other's hands.
DEADLINE: 140 PAGES
INT. HOUSE - NIGHT:
The family is sitting in their living room. The parents are sitting on the couch while their two kids are watching a movie.
DAD
Alright, guys, it's past your bedtime but I'm going to let you finish the movie.
The kids start jumping around in excitement.
The phone rings. The mom answers it.
MOM
Hello?
The dad looks at her with a questioning look.
MOM
(into the phone) No, nothing. What is it? (pauses) OK, I'll tell him. (pauses) Alright, I'll call you back. (hands the phone to her husband)
DAD
(answers the phone) Hello?
The camera slowly zooms in on the dad's face.
DEADLINE: 150 PAGES
THE END</s>

instruction:
You should write a well-structured screenplay based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: A birthday party goes wrong when the boy's father returns home drunk and aggressive.
[Requirements]:
1. Start with a slugline (e.g., INT. HOUSE - NIGHT) that sets the scene.
2. Introduce the main characters and setting in the opening scene.
3. Write dialogues that reveal character traits, relationships, and move the plot forward.
4. Include action lines and stage directions to describe movements, expressions, and scene changes.
5. Feel free to use creativity to bring the writing prompt to life, creating an engaging and dynamic screenplay.
6. Ensure the screenplay is detailed and long enough.
response:
Title: A Birthday Gone Wrong
---
**INT. HOUSE - NIGHT**
A house, dim lit, with a few candles lit. The house is decorated with balloons and streamers. A group of children are inside the house, sitting in the living room playing video games. One of the children's, MICHAEL, is turning 10 years old today and he's excited for his birthday party.
**INT. HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT**
**MICHAEL**
(cheerfully)
I can't believe I'm turning 10 today!
**TAMMY**
(grinning)
You're gonna get old someday, you know that?
**MICHAEL**
(excitedly)
Wow, you're such a good friend, Tammy! I don't know what I'd do without you!
**TAMMY**
(smiling)
You've got me, Michael. For life.
**MICHAEL**
(grinning)
You're the best!
**Tammy**
**
The children continue to play video games, having a great time together. Michael is having a great time with his friends, but he's impatiently waiting for his dad to come home.
**MICHAEL**
(excitedly)
Dad's coming home! He's gonna be here soon!
**DAVID**
(groans)
Can we just go on with the game?
**TAMMY**
(smiling)
Sure! Let's just wait a bit more.
Michael turns to look at the door, impatiently waiting for his dad to come home. Tammy smiles and looks at Michael, comforting him. Suddenly, the door opens and the children's father walks in.
**MICHAEL**
(excitedly)
Dad! You're here!
**DAVID**
(excitedly)
Dad!
**FATHER**
(gruffly)
What? Get off my shoes!
David and Michael look at each other in confusion, not knowing what their dad meant.
**FATHER**
(stomps foot)
What do you want?
**DAVID**
(excitedly)
It's Michael's birthday! We're having a birthday party!
**FATHER**
(annoyed)
Birthday party? Get out of my house!
**DAVID**
(panicked)
But Dad!
**FATHER**
(irritated)
I don't want any children in my house!
**DAVID**
(confused)
But it's Michael's birthday!
**FATHER**
(angrily)
What? I don't care! Get out! I don't want you here!
Michael's friends are confused and start to get up from the couch, preparing to leave. Michael looks at his dad, not understanding why he's behaving so badly.
**MICHAEL**
(confused)
Dad? What's wrong?
**FATHER**
(irritated)
Nothing's wrong! Now get out!
**MICHAEL**
(stammering)
Dad...you're drunk, aren't you?
**FATHER**
(angrily)
Yes! I'm drunk! Now get out!
**MICHAEL**
(confused)
But...Dad...why are you being like this?
David and Tammy leave the house, feeling confused and upset by Michael's father. Michael looks at his dad, confused and heartbroken.
**FATHER**
(irritated)
I said get out!
**DAVID**
(upset)
I'm going, Dad.
**TAMMY**
(upset)
We're sorry. We'll go.
Michael looks at his dad, not knowing what to say or do. He feels confused and heartbroken by his dad's behavior.
**MICHAEL**
(upset)
Dad...I'm sorry. I didn't do anything wrong.
**FATHER**
(irritated)
Shut up! Now get out!
**MICHAEL**
(crying)
But Dad...
**FATHER**
(irritated)
I said get out!
Michael starts to cry, heartbroken by his dad's behavior. He feels confused and unsure of what to do, so he turns and runs to his room, crying.

**MICHAEL**

Michael stops and turns around, walking back to his dad. He's heartbroken and confused by his dad's behavior.

Michael walks over to his dad, standing in front of him. He's crying, heartbroken by his dad's behavior.
