instruction:
You should write an engaging story based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: You're a villain, but you typically hold back. You're into villainy for a quick robbery, or just some laughs. But not any more. Today is the day to show them that making you mad is a BAD idea.
[Requirements]:
1. Feel free to use creativity to expand on the prompt and create an interesting and captivating narrative.
2. Ensure the story is long enough.
response:
Today was the day I was going to show the world that making me mad is a bad idea. I've been in the villain game for a while now, and I've always been known for my quick robberies and the occasional prank. I'm not out to hurt people, I just like to have a little fun and make some extra money.
But that all changed today. I was walking through the city when I stumbled upon a group of teenagers, and I could tell they were up to no good. They were huddled around a man who was lying on the ground, groaning in pain. I walked closer to see what was happening.
The teens were surrounded the man, snickering and laughing. They had clearly caused his harm and were trying to make him feel even more miserable. I couldn't stand to see it, so I walked up to them and told them to knock it off.
They turned to me, and one of them gave me a dirty look. I thought it was strange, but didn't let it bother me. They were just a bunch of immature kids trying to cause trouble, and I was going to put a stop to it.
But things took a turn for the worse when one of the teens lunged at me with a knife. I ducked out of the way, but it was too late. I was cut on my left arm, and it was bleeding heavily.
I was shocked that these kids would do something like this, but I quickly realized that they didn't respect me. They were just taking advantage of my lack of intimidation, and it was time to teach them a lesson.
I reached for my gun, and before they knew what was happening, I opened fire. The kids were screaming and running in all directions, and the man on the ground was crying out in pain. I knew I had to do something to help him, so I ran over to him and pulled him to safety.
I was sure I had made a mistake, and that this would be the last time I would see him. But when I looked back, I saw that no one was left standing. The kids had scattered, and I was the only one left standing.
I couldn't believe it. I had just used my gun on a group of unarmed teenagers. I didn't know what had come over me, but I had just killed them all. I felt so guilty, and I didn't know what to do.
I ran away from the scene, and I didn't look back. I had to get away from there before anyone could recognize me. I knew this was going to be a bad day for me, and I wasn't sure how I was going to live with myself.
But, as I was running away, I knew that I had just made a mistake. I wasn't the type of villain to do something like this, and I couldn't live with myself if I didn't do something to fix it.
I had to get to my hideout, and quickly. I needed to think about what I was going to do, and I needed to do it quickly. I knew that I couldn't make things right without help, and I was going to have to be careful about who I turned to.
I finally made it to my hideout, and I was breathing heavily. I was so relieved to be there, and I knew that I could finally think about what I was going to do. I quickly grabbed my phone and dialed a number that I had saved in my phone.
"Hello," a voice said on the other end.
"Hello," I replied. "This is a difficult time for me. I'm sorry to bother you, but I need your help."
"What's going on?" the voice asked.
"I just made a grave mistake," I replied. "I just killed a group of teenagers who were teasing me, and I can't live with myself. I don't know what to do."
There was a pause, and then the voice said, "I'm sorry to hear that. What do you want me to do?"
"I need your help," I said. "I need you to come to my hideout and talk to me."
"Where are you?" the voice asked.
"I'm at my hideout," I replied. "You know where it is."
"Okay, I'll be there as soon as I can."
I hung up the phone, and I was filled with a sense of relief. I was glad that the person on the other end of the phone was willing to help me, and I was hoping that they would be able to help me fix the situation.
I was sitting in my hideout, waiting for my contact to arrive. It was a long wait, and I was starting to get nervous. I wasn't sure if they would be able to help me, and I was starting to doubt myself.
But then, I heard a knock on the door. I quickly stood up and walked over to the door. I opened it, and there stood my contact, dressed in a black suit and a black hat.
"Hello," I said, trying to sound nonchalant.
"Hello," the person replied. "I heard about what you did. Are you ready to talk about it?"
"I don't know what to do," I admitted. "I can't live with myself right now. I'm so scared. I don't know what's going to happen to me."
"Calm down," the person said. "Let's talk about this. What happened?"
"I was walking through the city, and I stumbled upon a group of teenagers who were teasing me. I asked them to stop, but they just laughed at me. Then, one of them took out a knife and tried to stab me. I opened fire, and I shot all of them."
"I see," the person said. "I understand why you did what you did, but you can't just go around killing people. You have to learn how to control your anger, and you have to learn how to be in control of yourself."
I nodded. I knew that the person was right. I had been feeling so angry, and I had let it get the best of me. I needed to learn how to control my anger, and I needed to learn how to be in control of myself.
"I know," I said. "I know what I need to do. Can you help me?"
"Of course," the person said. "I'll help you. You just have to be willing to listen to me, and you have to be willing to do what I say."
"I'll do whatever you say," I replied. "I need your help."
"I'll help you, but you have to understand that this is going to be a long and difficult process. You're going to have to learn how to control your anger, and you're going to have to learn how to be in control of yourself. It won't be easy, but I'll help you every step of the way."
"I understand," I said. "I'm willing to do whatever it takes."
"Good. Let's get started."
I nodded, and I followed the person out of the hideout. I was feeling so relieved to have someone to help me, and I was hoping that things would get better soon.
As we were walking, I asked the person, "Why did you agree to help me?"
"I like helping people," the person said. "I don't care if they're good or bad. I just like helping people, and I think you'll be a good person to help."
"I hope so," I said. "I really need your help."
"I'll help you," the person said. "I'll help you with anything you need. Just remember, you have to be willing to listen to me and do what I say. Do you understand?"
"Yes," I said. "I understand."
"Good. Let's get started."
We walked for a few more minutes, and then we arrived at the person's hideout. It was a large, luxurious house, and I was impressed by how much money the person had. I knew that they were a rich villain, but I had never seen their hideout before.
"Welcome to my hideout," the person said. "I hope you like it. I'll show you around later. Right now, I want to talk to you about what happened."
"Okay," I said. "I'm ready to listen. What do you want to talk about?"
"I want to talk about what you did," the person said. "I want to talk about how you can control your anger, and how you can be in control of yourself."
"I understand," I said. "I'm ready to talk about it."
"Good," the person said. "Let's get started."
We sat down in a large, comfortable chair, and the person started talking to me. I listened carefully to everything they said, and I tried to absorb as much information as I could.
"What happened was a mistake," the person said. "You made a mistake, and now you're going to have to pay for it. You're going to have to learn how to control your anger, and you're going to have to learn how to be in control of yourself."
"I understand," I said. "I know that I made a mistake. I'm sorry, and I'm willing to do whatever it takes to fix it."
"Good," the person said. "I know you're sorry, and I know you're willing to do whatever it takes. That's good. Now, let's talk about how you can control your anger, and how you can be in control of yourself."
The person started talking about different techniques that I could use to control my anger, and how I could be in control of myself. I listened carefully to everything they said, and I tried to absorb as much information as I could.
I learned how to control my breathing, and I learned how to relax my muscles. I learned how to think about different things to calm myself down, and I learned how to control my thoughts. I learned how to be in control of myself, and how to control my anger.
I practiced everything the person taught me, and I was starting to feel more in control of myself. I was starting to feel more confident, and I was starting to feel more in control of my anger. I was hoping that things would get better soon.
"How do you feel?" the person asked me.
"I feel a lot better," I said. "I feel more in control of myself, and I feel more in control of my anger. I'm starting to feel more confident, and I'm starting to feel more in control of my thoughts."
"That's good to hear," the person said. "I'm glad you're feeling better. Do you have any questions?"
"No," I said. "I don't have any questions. I understand everything you've taught me, and I'm ready to do whatever it takes to fix what I did."
"Good," the person said. "I'm glad you understand. Now, I have something I want to ask you. Do you want to work with me?"
"Yes," I said. "I want to work with you. I want to be your partner in crime."
"Excellent," the person said. "I'm glad you want to work with me. I have a lot of work to do, and I need someone to help me. I think we'll make a good team."
"I think so too," I said. "I think we'll make a good team. I'm ready to help you."
"Excellent," the person said. "I'm glad you're ready to help me. Now, I have to ask you something. Do you want to be my partner in crime?"
"Yes," I said. "I want to be your partner in crime. I'm ready to help you."
"Excellent," the person said. "I'm glad you want to be my partner in crime. I have a lot of work to do, and I need someone to help me. I think we'll make a good team."
"I think so too," I said. "I think we'll make a good team. I'm ready to help you."
"Let's get started," the person said. "I have to tell you about my plan, and I have to tell you what you're going to do."
"Okay," I said. "I'm ready to listen. What do you want to talk about?"
"I want to talk about my plan," the person said. "I want to talk about what you're going to do, and I want to talk about how we're going to work together."
"Okay," I said. "I'm ready to listen. What's your plan?"
"My plan is to take over the city," the person said. "I want to be the most powerful person in the city, and I want to be the most feared person in the city. I want people to cower before me, and I want people to do anything I say."
"That's a great plan," I said. "I'm ready to help you take over the city. I'm ready to do anything you say.</s>

instruction:
You should write an engaging story based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: "Hate humanity? What makes you think that? Do you hate the bugs that splatter across your windshields? No, they're just... in the way."
[Requirements]:
1. Feel free to use creativity to expand on the prompt and create an interesting and captivating narrative.
2. Ensure the story is long enough.
response:
"Hate humanity? What makes you think that?"
I chuckled. "Oh, you know. The usual stuff. Traffic jams. Noise pollution. The fact that I once got bit by a rat in a subway station. No, wait, that was a different subway system. But still. You get the picture."
I glanced down at the newspaper I was holding. The headline read "More and More People Dying from Disease," and I could feel my pulse quicken. I crumpled the paper into a tight ball, and shoved it deep into a brown paper bag.
"No, that's not it," I said again. "I hate... bugs. I hate the way the ants make that weird, spiky pattern when they walk in large groups. I hate the way the mosquitoes land on you in the middle of the night and make their bloodsucking sounds. I hate the way flies buzz in and out of your ears. I hate the way spiders always know exactly where you want to step. And I hate the way cockroaches have those weird, shiny antennae that keep jumping around."
I paused, and took a deep breath. "No, actually I don't hate bugs. I just don't like them. I don't hate humans, either. In fact, I like humans quite a lot. They're interesting, and funny, and sometimes they even smell nice. When I sit on a park bench, I like to watch the people walking by. I like to see how kids make the world look bigger than it is. I like the way grown-ups look like they have places to be and things to do. I like how they talk to me sometimes, or smile at me in the street. I like the way they sit on benches and read things and drink out of paper cups. I like their shoes! Most of the time, anyway. I like the way they laugh, and dance, and sing, and run. And I like how they love. I know how hard it is to love, and most of the time I wouldn't do it. But I like the way they do it. It's a good thing."
I smiled. "But I guess that's where I'm not so much like them. I don't know how to love. I've never really known anyone I love, except maybe my mom. She was there for me when I was a baby. And she's been gone for a long time. But I miss her, anyway. She was a good mom. She told me I was funny when I was a kid. I guess that's why I am."
I looked around me. I saw a trash can with a lid on it, and I jumped up to get it. I climbed up onto the lid, and then I saw a group of pigeons. They were eating some pieces of bread. I took off my jacket and flapped my arms. The pigeons got startled and flew away. A couple of them landed on a nearby tree, and I climbed down. I put my jacket back on and looked at my hands. They were dirty.
"I guess I hate that," I said. "I hate being dirty. I hate the way some people are always telling me to wash my hands. It's like they think I don't know. It's like they think I'm too stupid or too lazy to do it myself. I hate that, too. I hate being told what to do. I hate the way people look at me when I'm walking past them. I hate the way they make things up about me. I hate the way they make me feel like I'm not really a person. I hate the way they make me feel like I'm not even real."
I put my hands on my hips. "I'll tell you what I hate. I hate that there's a war going on. I hate that people are dying in the streets. I hate that people are losing their homes because of the economy. I hate that the water in Flint, Michigan, is so toxic that it's poisoning the kids there. I hate that we live in a world where it's okay to be rich and it's okay to be poor, and where that makes all the difference. I hate that some people are so mean, and some people are so cruel, and some people are so unkind. I hate the way we treat animals, and I hate the way we treat the planet. I hate the way we keep building more cars and more factories and more apartments and more stores, and the way we keep polluting the air and the water and the soil. I hate the way we keep taking and taking and taking. I hate the way we keep ignoring what's happening right in front of our eyes."
I shook my head. "I don't hate humans, though. I don't hate them. But I don't like them, either. I don't trust them, and I don't think they should be trusted. I don't think they're good enough, and I don't think they're smart enough. I don't think they're strong enough. I don't think they're worth saving. And I don't think they should be saved, either. I don't think we should save them. I think we should let them go. I think we should just let them die out."
I looked down at the paper bag in my hands. I took it out and opened it. The crumpled newspaper fell to the ground. "That's what I think. That's what I believe."
I stood up. "But you know what? I think there are a lot of things I don't understand. I think there are a lot of things I don't know. I think there are a lot of things I don't comprehend. And I think there are a lot of things I should be ashamed of. I don't want to be ashamed of them, but I am. And I don't want to be ashamed of anything else, either. So I guess I can't hate them, right? I can't hate humans. I just can't.</s>

instruction:
You should write an engaging story based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: "Conquer" was the last word of the Galactus Emperor. Thus, his people set about a campaign to rule everything by force, in His name. Then they find out a half century later that the data of his last words was corrupted and he'd said, "Conquer fear and bring hope to the galaxy."
[Requirements]:
1. Feel free to use creativity to expand on the prompt and create an interesting and captivating narrative.
2. Ensure the story is long enough.
response:
The Galactus Emperor had ruled over the galaxy for over half a century. His people, known as the Galactusians, had been his faithful servants. They had conquered many worlds over the centuries, and had made the Galactus Empire one of the strongest in the galaxy.
But that all came to an end when the Galactus Emperor passed away. The Galactusians were devastated, but they had a plan. They would continue to conquer in his name. And that is what they did.
The Galactus Empire grew stronger and stronger by the day. They conquered more and more worlds, and brought all of them under their rule. They were the strongest in the galaxy, and everyone knew it.
But then, one day, fifty years after the Galactus Emperor's death, something strange happened. They discovered that the data of his last words was corrupted. What he had actually said was, "Conquer fear and bring hope to the galaxy."
The Galactusians were shocked. They had been conquerors for so long, but now they realized that they had been doing the wrong thing all along. They had been taking away hope from the people they had conquered.
So, they decided to change their ways. They left the conquered worlds, and started to give them hope. They helped the people rebuild their lives, and gave them a chance to live in peace.
It was a big change for the Galactusians, but they were determined to do what was right. They worked hard to bring hope to the galaxy, and soon, they became known as heroes.
The people of the galaxy loved them for it. They were no longer feared, but respected. The Galactusians were happy. They had finally found their purpose.
And so, the Galactusians lived happily ever after, bringing hope to the galaxy.
But there was one thing that still bothered them. They could never know what the Galactus Emperor would have thought of their change of heart. Would he have been proud of them? Or would he have been disappointed that they had taken so long to understand?
They could never know. But they could be sure of one thing. They had learned from their mistakes. They had learned to conquer fear, and bring hope to the galaxy. And that was all that mattered.</s>

instruction:
You should write an engaging story based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: You were supposed to be a supervillain. Unfortunately, your monologues were way too convincing. Now you need to figure out how to manage an entire country of rabid supporters.
[Requirements]:
1. Feel free to use creativity to expand on the prompt and create an interesting and captivating narrative.
2. Ensure the story is long enough.
response:
Once upon a time in a small town nestled in the rolling hills of a peaceful countryside, there lived a man named Alistair. He was known throughout the town as a mild-mannered family man, a devoted husband, and a loving father of three. He was also notorious as a criminal mastermind, a cunning and dangerous thief, and an all-around menace to society. Alistair was a supervillain, and he had a plan.
Alistair's plan was simple, but brilliant. It was perfect. He planned to take over the world. To do so, he needed money. Lots of money. And so, he planned a series of elaborate heists, each one bigger and bolder than the last. He planned to rob the Federal Reserve and steal enough money to buy the world. He had it all planned out. He would rob the bank on the night of the full moon, wearing a ski mask and wielding a ray gun, a weapon of his own invention that could knock out anyone who saw him. It was foolproof.
So it was that, on the night of the full moon, Alistair entered the Federal Reserve wearing his ski mask and carrying his ray gun. He was ready for action. He crept through the dark halls of the building, careful to avoid the guards, and found his way to the vault. He was so excited, he could hardly contain himself. He was almost there.
When he opened the vault door, he was shocked by what he found. Instead of stacks and stacks of cash, he found only an empty vault. He was confused. Had the bank already been robbed? No, that couldn't be. He had planned this heist to the last detail. It was supposed to be foolproof.
Alistair scratched his head, trying to figure out what had gone wrong. He was starting to get a little worried. He had to get out of there before he was caught. He turned to leave. That's when he saw her.
A woman in a red dress and heels, wielding a shotgun, blocked his way. "I'm afraid you can't leave, Mr. Villain," she said. "You see, I was expecting you."
Alistair looked at her, dumbfounded. This was not part of the plan. He had never even considered the possibility that someone might be waiting for him. He was about to ask how she knew his true identity when he saw the crowd of people gathered behind her. There were more than 20,000 of them. All of them were shouting, "Alistair! Alistair! We love you! We adore you! You're our hero!"
Alistair stared at the crowd in shock. He had never expected this. He had spent so much time making himself into a criminal mastermind, and now they loved him for it. What had he done? He was about to say something when the woman in the red dress spoke up again.
"Alistair," she said. "I'm afraid I have some bad news. Your speech was way too convincing."
The crowd began to chant. "Alistair! Alistair! We will follow you! We will do anything for you! ALISTAIR FOR PRESIDENT!"
Alistair was absolutely dumbfounded. What had he done? He hadn't meant to be a hero. He had meant to be a supervillain. He looked at the woman in the red dress. "You have to help me," he said. "I don't know what to do."
"Well, you certainly can't become a villain," she said. "You've already been voted out of office. I'm afraid you'll just have to learn how to manage your own country."
"My country?" Alistair asked.
"Yes," the woman in red said. "When you became president, you not only gained the loyalty of the entire country, you also inherited a massive debt, a corrupt government, and a host of rabid supporters. You'll need to figure out how to manage all of that."
Alistair looked at the crowd. They were still chanting his name. They were still demanding that he be their president. There was no way out of it. He was stuck. He looked back at the woman in red. "I don't know anything about running a country," he said. "Can't you help me?"
"I can," she said. "But you'll have to learn. You've got a whole nation to lead, and you can't just walk away from that. You're a supervillain, after all."
"What do I do?" Alistair asked.
"You'll have to start by learning how to make decisions," the woman in red said. "You can't be a hero and a villain at the same time. You'll have to pick one. Then, you'll have to figure out how to keep your government running smoothly. You won't have much luck if you can't even manage your own country."
"I don't know how to do that," Alistair said.
"You'll learn," the woman in red said. "You have no choice."
Alistair nodded. He was starting to get a little nervous. He looked at the crowd. They were still chanting his name. He wasn't sure he could do this. He wasn't sure he even wanted to. He turned to the woman in red. "I need help," he said.
"I'll help you," the woman in red said. "But you'll have to remember that, once you become president, I'll be your only advisor."
"I can't be your only advisor," Alistair said. "I'll need other people to help me."
"You'll have to find other people to help you," the woman in red said. "I'm the only one you can trust."
"I can't be your only advisor," Alistair said. "I can't just rely on one person. I'll need other people, too."
"Alistair," the woman in red said. "You have no choice."
"I can't do this alone," Alistair said.
"You'll have to figure it out," the woman in red said. "If you want to be a supervillain, you'll have to do it on your own."
Alistair nodded. He was starting to get really scared. He didn't want to be a supervillain. He didn't want to be president. He didn't want to be anyone's hero. He just wanted to go back to his quiet life in the small town in the rolling hills of the countryside.
But he knew he couldn't do that. He knew that once he became president, there was no going back. He had no choice. He was stuck. He was a supervillain, and he had to learn how to be one.
So he took a deep breath and stepped forward. He gave a speech to the crowd, saying all the things he knew they wanted to hear. He promised to make their country great again, to bring back the glory days, to make them all rich and powerful.
The crowd went wild. They loved what he had to say. They were ready to follow him anywhere.
Alistair turned to the woman in red. "I need your help," he said.
"I'll help you," the woman in red said.
"I need you to show me how to be a supervillain," Alistair said.
"I'll teach you everything you need to know about being a supervillain," the woman in red said.
"You'll show me how to run a country?" Alistair asked.
"I'll show you everything you need to know about running a country," the woman in red said. "But you'll have to learn how to be a supervillain first."
"How do I do that?" Alistair asked.
"You'll have to figure it out on your own," the woman in red said.
Alistair nodded. He knew that, once he became president, there was no going back. He had to figure it out on his own. He took a deep breath and stepped forward again.
This time, the crowd was silent. They were all watching him, waiting to see what he would do next.
He looked at the woman in red. She was smiling at him. He knew she was proud of him, that she thought he could do it. He knew he could do it. He knew that, if he tried hard enough, he could be a supervillain.
He looked at the crowd. They were watching him, waiting for him to make the first move.
"I'm a supervillain," he said. "And I'm going to be the greatest supervillain in the history of the world."
The crowd went wild. They cheered and shouted and chanted his name. They loved him for who he was. They loved him for what he was going to be.
"I'm a supervillain," Alistair repeated. "And I'm going to be the greatest supervillain in the history of the world."
And so it was that Alistair became a supervillain. He learned how to be a supervillain, and he learned how to be a president. He learned how to manage a country, and he learned how to get things done. He learned how to balance a budget and how to put together a team. He learned how to make tough decisions and how to get the job done.
He learned how to be a hero.
And that's how Alistair became the greatest supervillain in the history of the world.
As a supervillain, he could do anything he wanted. He could fly to the moon, blow up the world, or take over the universe if he wanted to. He could do whatever he wanted, and no one could stop him.
As a supervillain, he could do anything he wanted.
But he chose not to.

instruction:
You should write an engaging story based on the following writing prompt.
[Writing Prompt]: Your wife/husband of 35 years comes to you looking dazed. "I fell. I think I hurt my head." You turn them around and are stunned to see a large gash in the back of their head exposing tiny flickering lights and wires.
[Requirements]:
1. Feel free to use creativity to expand on the prompt and create an interesting and captivating narrative.
2. Ensure the story is long enough.
response:
I never thought I would see the day where I questioned the reality of my own life, yet here I am.
I sit down at the kitchen table with my wife of 35 years, looking at her dazedly. She blinks a few times and looks at me with a confused expression. I start to tell her what I saw, but I can't seem to get the words out. I grab her hand and turn her around so she is facing the window. The reflection shows a large gash in the back of her head, exposing tiny flickering lights and wires.
"I don't understand," she says. "What are you talking about?"
She turns her head to look at me, and I see the confusion in her eyes. I know that this is reality, but I can't shake the feeling that this is all wrong.
"Amy, please don't tell me that you don't see it," I say.
"See what?" she asks.
"The wires. The lights. They're coming out of your head!" I exclaim.
She looks at the window again and shakes her head. "I don't see anything," she says.
I burst into tears.
"What's wrong, honey?" she asks, patting my hand.
I can't speak. I can't think. All I can do is cry.
Suddenly, she stands up and goes to the bathroom. I hear the shower running, and then she comes back out, still without any indication that anything is wrong.
I follow her to the bedroom where she sits down on the bed.
"Do you want to talk about it?" she asks.
"Talk about what?" I ask.
"Well, you've been very quiet. I think you need to talk about what's bothering you."
I shake my head. "I don't know what's bothering me," I say.
"Okay, well, talk about that then," she says, smiling.
I look at her, and I start to laugh. "You're so weird," I say.
"Hey, I'm just trying to help you," she says.
"I know, I'm sorry," I say.
"It's okay," she says.
"I just don't understand. I saw something that wasn't there. I saw wires and lights coming out of your head."
She looks at me and smiles. "Honey, you were just seeing things," she says.
"But they were real," I say.
"James, you were just tired. You needed to get some sleep."
"But I wasn't tired," I say.
"You've been working a lot lately. You need to take a break. Why don't we go to bed?" she suggests.
"Okay," I say.
We go to bed and I try to fall asleep. I can't shake the feeling that something is wrong. Something isn't right.
I start to feel a pain in my head. I try to ignore it, but it gets worse. I sit up and start to feel around my head. I find a lump and I feel like I'm going to be sick.
I grab my phone and call the doctor's office. The receptionist tells me that the doctor isn't in today, but she can make an appointment for me for tomorrow.
"What do you mean you can't see me today?" I say.
"I'm sorry, sir. The doctor isn't in today. He'll be back tomorrow."
"But I need to see him today," I say.
"I'm sorry, sir. I can't make an appointment for you today."
"Please. I need to see him. It's urgent," I beg.
"I'm sorry, sir. I'm the only receptionist today. I can't make an appointment for you."
"Please. I'll do anything," I plead.
"I'm sorry, but the doctor is not available today. Will tomorrow work for you?"
I start to feel dizzy. "No, tomorrow won't work for me. Tomorrow is too late," I say.
"I'm sorry, sir. I can't help you. The doctor is not available today."
I hang up the phone and lie down on the bed. I feel like I'm going to die.
"James? Are you okay?" Amy asks.
"I'm not feeling very good," I say.
"Do you want me to call the doctor?" she asks.
"No, it's okay. I'll be fine," I say.
I start to feel even more dizzy, and I can't keep my eyes open. I close them and try to sleep.
When I wake up, I'm in a hospital bed. I look around and see my wife next to me.
"What's going on?" I ask.
"You had a seizure. The doctor said that you hit your head and you have a concussion," she says.
"What? How did I hit my head?" I ask.
"You must have fallen," she says.
"I don't remember falling," I say.
"Well, you must have. The doctor said that you hit your head pretty hard," she says.
"What happened after I hit my head?" I ask.
"The doctor said that you were hallucinating. You saw wires and lights coming out of my head," she says.
I start to feel very scared. "What do you mean I was hallucinating? What was I seeing?" I ask.
"The doctor said that it was just your brain trying to process the trauma," she says.
"But I wasn't hallucinating. I saw something," I say.
"James, please. You need to rest. The doctor said that you should rest and avoid any strenuous activity for a few days," she says.
I look at her and I start to feel like something is very wrong. I know that I saw wires and lights coming out of her head, but the doctor said that I was hallucinating. I don't understand. I don't understand anything.
"I don't believe you," I say.
"Believe what?" she asks.
"I don't believe that I was hallucinating," I say.
"James, please. You need to rest. The doctor said that you should rest and avoid any strenuous activity for a few days," she says.
"No. I need to know what's happening. I need to know why I saw what I saw," I say.
"James, please. You need to rest. The doctor said that you should rest and avoid any strenuous activity for a few days," she says.
I start to feel very angry. "No. I'm not going to rest. I need to know what's happening. I need to know why I saw what I saw," I say.
